name: Aardvark
description: The aardvark has a hunched body, a small head with an elongated snout ending in a broad muzzle, large funnel-shaped ears, and muscular legs with four toes on the front and five on the back, each tipped with strong claws.
proportions: Body length 1–1.6 m; tail length 45–70 cm; shoulder height 60–65 cm; weight 40–100 kg
attractions: At night, it tirelessly roams the landscape, digging into ant and termite mounds with its long, sticky tongue to extract startled insects, crushing them with flat, undifferentiated molars—it lacks developed incisors or canines. It sleeps in underground burrows by day, often shared by a male and female, though some aardvarks live solitarily.
breeding: The first pair, females Bojsa and Nebojsa, arrived at the zoo in 1978. Until 2001, they lived in quarantine areas, visible to visitors only on hot summer days in an outdoor enclosure. The first successful breeding occurred in 1989.
